{{short description|Canadian writer}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Use Canadian English|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Gavin McInnes |image = Gavin-McInnes-2015.png |alt = |caption = McInnes hosting his show in 2015 |birth_name = Gavin Miles McInnes |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1970|07|17}} |birth_place = [[Hitchin]], England |home_town = [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]], Canada |residence = [[New York City]] |citizenship = Canadian |alma_mater = |occupation = Writer, comedian, actor, commentator, columnist
|spouse = {{marriage|Emily Jendrisak|2005}} |children = 3 }} {{Infobox YouTube personality|silver_button=yes|silver_year=2016|gold_button=no|gold_year=}}
'''Gavin Miles McInnes''' ({{IPAc-en|m|ə|ˈ|k|ɪ|n|ᵻ|s}}; born 17 July 1970) is a Canadian writer, actor, and comedian. He is the co-founder of [[Vice Media]] and [[Vice (magazine)|''Vice Magazine'']]<ref name="Pareene" /><ref name="gakwertwo">{{cite news |work=[[Gawker]] |title=The 'Vice' Boys Are All Grown Up And Working For Viacom |url=http://gawker.com/324484/the-vice-boys-are-all-grown-up-and-working-for-viacom |date=19 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120407104804/http://gawker.com/324484/the-vice-boys-are-all-grown-up-and-working-for-viacom |archivedate=7 April 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/oct/28/terry-richardson-porn-chic-moulded-look-era-fashion-industry-photographer|title=How Terry Richardson created porn ‘chic’ and moulded the look of an era|first=Richard|last=Benson|date=28 October 2017|accessdate=29 October 2017|website=Theguardian.com}}</ref> and host of ''Get Off My Lawn'' on [[Conservative Review]]. He is a contributor to ''[[Taki's Magazine]]'' and a former contributor to [[The Rebel Media]], and was a frequent guest on television programs on [[Fox News]] and [[TheBlaze]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Stephens |first=Chase |date=12 February 2016 |title=McInnes: Dear Feminists, Men Have It Worse In All Areas Including Being Raped |url=http://www.dailywire.com/news/3335/dear-feminists-men-have-it-worse-all-areas-chase-stephens |website=The Daily Wire |access-date=7 August 2016}}</ref>
McInnes was a leading figure in the [[Hipster (contemporary subculture)|hipster]] subculture while at Vice, being labelled as the "godfather" of hipsterdom. After leaving the company in 2008, he became increasingly known for his [[Far-right politics|far-right]] political views.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/16/nyregion/proud-boys-gavin-mcinnes.html|title=Proud Boys Founder: How He Went From Brooklyn Hipster to Far-Right Provocateur|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en}}</ref> He is the founder of the [[Proud Boys]], a chauvinist men's group considered an extremist organisation by the [[FBI]] and the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/nov/19/proud-boys-fbi-classification-extremist-group-white-nationalism-report|title=FBI now classifies far-right Proud Boys as 'extremist group', documents say|last=Wilson|first=Jason|date=2018-11-19|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-11-22}}</ref>
==Early life== McInnes was born in [[Hitchin]] in [[Hertfordshire]], England, to [[Scottish people|Scottish]] parents, James and Loraine McInnes.<ref name="gawker">{{cite web|publisher=Gawker |title=Emily Jendriasak and Gavin McInnes |url=http://gawker.com/127848/vows-emily-jendriasak-and-gavin-mcinnes |website=Gawker.com |accessdate=10 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160311013944/http://gawker.com/127848/vows-emily-jendriasak-and-gavin-mcinnes |archivedate=11 March 2016}}</ref> His family migrated to Canada when McInnes was four.<ref>{{cite web|last=Shaidle |first=Kathy |url=http://takimag.com/article/10_great_things_about_the_brits_gavin_mcinnes/print |title=10 Great Things About the Brits - Taki's Magazine |website=Takimag.com |date=27 December 2013 |accessdate=10 March 2016}}</ref> He attended [[Ottawa]]'s [[Earl of March Secondary School]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=McInnes|first1=Gavin|authorlink1=Gavin McInnes|title=The Death of Cool: From Teenage Rebellion to the Hangover of Adulthood|date=2013|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9781451614183|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Oa4AAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA1#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=31 March 2018|language=en}}</ref> As a teen, McInnes played in the Ottawa [[punk band]] ''Anal Chinook''.<ref name="Nightlife.ca">{{cite web|url=http://www.nightlife.ca/arts-culture/vice-co-founder-gavin-mcinnes-montreal-junkies-fox-news-and-death-cool |title=Vice co-founder Gavin McInnes on Montreal junkies, Fox News and the death of cool |website=Nightlife.Ca |date=14 March 2012 |accessdate=10 March 2016}}</ref> As an adult, McInnes emigrated to the United States from Canada.
==Career== McInnes co-founded [[Vice (magazine)|''Vice'']] in 1994 with [[Shane Smith (journalist)|Shane Smith]] and [[Suroosh Alvi]].<ref name="gakwertwo"/> During his tenure there he was described as the "godfather" of [[hipster (contemporary subculture)|hipsterdom]] by [[WNBC]]<ref name="god">{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/blogs/niteside/Gavin-McInnes-on-Vice-I-Havent-Seen-It-In-A-While-91687159.html |title="Vice" Founder Gavin McInnes on Split From Glossy: "It's Like a Divorce" |publisher=NBC New York |author=Mawuse Ziegbe |accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> and as "one of hipsterdom’s primary architects" by ''[[AdBusters]]''.<ref name="hadow">{{cite web |url=https://www.adbusters.org/article/hipster-the-dead-end-of-western-civilization/ |title=Hipster: The Dead End of Western Civilization |author=Douglas Haddow |publisher=Adbusters |date=29 July 2008 |accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> He occasionally contributed articles to ''Vice'', including "The VICE Guide to Happiness"<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.vice.com/read/the-vice-v10n1|title=The VICE Guide To Happiness |website=Vice|language=en-us|access-date=1 April 2016}}</ref> and "The VICE Guide to Picking Up Chicks",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/read/poster-v12n1|title=The VICE Guide to Picking Up Chicks |website=Vice|language=en-us|access-date=1 April 2016}}</ref> and co-authored two ''Vice'' books: ''The Vice Guide to Sex and Drugs and Rock and Roll'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/606.The_Vice_Guide_to_Sex_and_Drugs_and_Rock_and_Roll |title=The Vice Guide to Sex and Drugs and Rock and Roll |publisher=Goodreads |access-date=2 April 2016}}</ref> and ''Vice Dos and Don'ts: 10 Years of VICE Magazine's Street Fashion Critiques''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/618.Vice_Dos_and_Don_ts|title=Vice Dos and Don'ts|publisher=Goodreads|access-date=2 April 2016}}</ref>
In an interview in the ''[[New York Press]]'' in 2002, McInnes said that he was pleased that most [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn|Williamsburg]] [[Hipster (contemporary subculture)|hipsters]] were white.<ref name="NYP">{{cite web|date=8 October 2002|title=Vice Rising: Corporate Media Woos Magazine World's Punks|url=http://www.nypress.com/vice-rising-corporate-media-woos-magazine-worlds-punks/|publisher=New York Press}}</ref><ref name="NYT" /> McInnes later wrote in a letter to [[Gawker]] that the interview was done as a prank intended to ridicule "baby boomer media like ''The Times''".<ref>{{cite web|author=Gavin McInnes |url=http://gawker.com/013468/letter-to-gawker-from-gavin-mcinnes |title=Letter to Gawker from Gavin McInnes |publisher=Gawker.com |date= |accessdate=10 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304070627/http://gawker.com/013468/letter-to-gawker-from-gavin-mcinnes |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df= }}</ref> After he became the focus of a letter-writing campaign by a black reader, ''Vice'' apologized for McInnes's comments.<ref name="NYT" /> McInnes was featured in a 2003 ''[[New York Times]]'' article about ''Vice'' magazine expressing his political views.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/28/style/the-edge-of-hip-vice-the-brand.html|title=The Edge of Hip: Vice, the Brand|date=28 September 2003|work=The New York Times|accessdate=8 February 2016}}</ref>
In 2006, he was featured in ''[[The Vice Guide to Travel]]'' with actor and comedian [[David Cross]] in China.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gavin McInnes|title=DAVID CROSS IN CHINA (part 1)|date=2 August 2007|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aOBJivqJ5Qo|website=Youtube.com|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref> He left ''Vice'' in 2008 due to what he described as "creative differences".<ref name="Pareene">{{cite web|url=http://gawker.com/348019/co-founder-gavin-mcinnes-finally-leaves-vice |title=Co-Founder Gavin McInnes Finally Leaves 'Vice' |author=Alex Pareene |publisher=Gawker |date=23 January 2008 |accessdate=14 December 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161010093200/http://gawker.com/348019/co-founder-gavin-mcinnes-finally-leaves-vice |archivedate=10 October 2016 |df= }}</ref> In a 2013 interview with ''[[The New Yorker]]'', McInnes said his split with ''Vice'' was about the increasing influence of corporate advertising on ''Vice's'' content, stating that "Marketing and editorial being enemies had been the business plan".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/04/08/the-bad-boy-brand|title=The Bad-Boy Brand |last=Widdicombe |first=Lizzie|date=8 April 2013|newspaper=[[The New Yorker]]|issn=0028-792X|access-date=1 April 2016}}</ref>
In 2008, McInnes created the website ''StreetCarnage.com''. He also co-founded an [[advertising agency]] called Rooster where he serves as creative director.<ref name="adweek">{{cite news|last=Braiker|first=Brian|title=Creating Ads For People Who Hate Ads |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/creating-ads-people-who-hate-ads-132667|accessdate=24 August 2011 |newspaper=Adweek |date=20 June 2011}}</ref> In 2009, McInnes convinced a journalist at ''[[The Village Voice]]'' that he had been knocked out after losing a challenge to an [[Mixed martial arts|MMA]] fighter.<ref>Baron, Zach. [http://blogs.villagevoice.com/music/2009/05/_a_week_or_so.php "Gavin McInnes Gets Knocked the Fuck Out,"] ''Village Voice'' (5 May 2009).</ref> The footage was actually an outtake from a failed TV pilot.<ref>[http://relevantpictures.com/?p=82 "The Immersionist with Gavin McInnes,"] Relevant Pictures. Accessed 5 April 2011.</ref> In 2010, McInnes convinced a journalist at Gawker that he had eaten a bowl of urine-soaked [[corn flakes]] after not winning their "Hipster of the Decade" competition.<ref>Kamer, Foster. [http://gawker.com/5438432/hipster-of-the-decade-loser-gavin-mcinnes-accepts-award-by-eating-bowl-of-pissed+in-cereal "Hipster of the Decade Loser Gavin McInnes Accepts 'Award' by Eating Bowl of Pissed-In Cereal,"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100708170145/http://gawker.com/5438432/hipster-of-the-decade-loser-gavin-mcinnes-accepts-award-by-eating-bowl-of-pissed+in-cereal |date=8 July 2010 }} Gawker (2 January 2010).</ref> The footage was actually an outtake from a collection of comedy sketches called ''Gavin McInnes Is a Fucking Asshole''.<ref name="streetcarnage.bigcartel">{{cite web |url=http://streetcarnage.bigcartel.com/product/gavin-mcinnes-is-a-fucking-asshole-dvd |title=''Gavin McInnes Is a Fucking Asshole'' DVD |publisher=Street Carnage |date= |accessdate=31 October 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029210257/http://streetcarnage.bigcartel.com/product/gavin-mcinnes-is-a-fucking-asshole-dvd/ |archive-date=29 October 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
McInnes was featured in Season 3 of the Canadian reality TV show ''[[Kenny vs. Spenny]]'', as a judge in the "Who is Cooler?" episode. In 2010, McInnes was approached by [[Adult Swim]] and asked to play the part of Mick, an anthropomorphic Scottish soccer ball, in the short-lived ''[[Aqua Teen Hunger Force]]'' spin-off ''[[Soul Quest Overdrive]]''.<ref name="roosternewyork.com">{{cite web|url=http://roosternewyork.com/2011/05/adult-swim-soul-quest-overdrive/|title=ADULT SWIM – SOUL QUEST OVERDRIVE|publisher=Rooster|date=27 May 2011|accessdate=3 July 2015}}</ref> After losing a 2010 pilot contest to ''[[Cheyenne Cinnamon and the Fantabulous Unicorn of Sugar Town Candy Fudge]]'', six episodes of ''Soul Quest Overdrive'' were ordered, with four airing in Adult Swim's 4 AM DVR Theater block on 25 May 2011 before quickly being cancelled. McInnes jokingly blamed the show's cancellation on the other cast members ([[Kristen Schaal]], [[David Cross]], and [[H. Jon Benjamin]]) not being "as funny" as him.<ref name="streetcarnage.com">{{cite web|url=http://streetcarnage.com/blog/soul-quest-overdrive-watch-the-whole-series-here/|title=SOUL QUEST OVERDRIVE: WATCH THE WHOLE SERIES HERE|publisher=StreetCarnage.com|date=27 May 2011|accessdate=3 July 2015}}</ref>
In 2012, McInnes wrote a book called ''How to Piss in Public''.<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|url=http://thoughtcatalog.com/paul-barker/2012/04/gavin-mcinnes-how-to-piss-in-public-extensive-interview/|title=Gavin McInnes: An In-depth Interview With "The Godfather of Hipsterdom"|work=Thought Catalog|accessdate=8 February 2016}}</ref> In 2013 he directed ''The Brotherhood of the Traveling Rants'', a documentary on his tour as an occasional standup comedian.<ref>Grant, Drew. [http://www.observer.com/2012/03/gavin-mcinnes-wrecks-car-loses-best-friend-in-an-attempt-to-win-back-dignity-after-punking-video/ "Gavin McInnes Wrecks Car, 'Loses' Best Friend in An Attempt to Win Back Dignity After Observer Punking (Video),"] The Observer (27 March 2012)</ref> For the film, he faked a serious car accident. Also that year, McInnes starred in the independent film ''[[How to Be a Man]]'', which premiered at [[Sundance Institute|Sundance Next Weekend]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sundance.org/festival/article/day-3-gavin-mcinnes-gets-unruly-in-how-to-be-a-man/|title=Day 3: Gavin McInnes’ Errant Life Tips in How To Be A Man; James Ponsoldt’s Advice to Filmmakers|publisher=[[Sundance Film Festival]]|date=August 11, 2013|first=Nate|last=von Zurmwall|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130815072739/http://www.sundance.org/festival/article/day-3-gavin-mcinnes-gets-unruly-in-how-to-be-a-man/|archive-date=August 15, 2013}}</ref> He has also played supporting roles in other films including ''[[Soul Quest Overdrive]]'' (2010), ''[[Creative Control (film)|Creative Control]]'' (2015) and ''[[One More Time (2015 film)|One More Time]]'' (2015).
In August 2014, McInnes was asked to take an indefinite leave of absence as chief creative officer of Rooster, following online publication at Thought Catalog of an essay about [[transphobia]] titled "Transphobia is Perfectly Natural"<ref name="TC">{{cite news|url=http://thoughtcatalog.com/gavin-mcinnes/2014/08/transphobia-is-perfectly-natural/ |title=Transphobia is Perfectly Natural |last=McInnes |first=Gavin |date=12 August 2014 |work=Thought Catalog |publisher=The Thought & Expression Company}} Click "Continue" link at the very bottom of the warning page to view original article.</ref> that sparked a call to boycott the company. In response, Rooster issued a statement, saying in part: "We are extremely disappointed with his actions and have asked that he take a leave of absence while we determine the most appropriate course of action."<ref name="Transphobia">{{cite news |last=Monllos |first=Kristina |title=Rooster CCO Gavin McInnes Asked to Take Leave of Absence Following transphobic Thought Catalog essay, boycott |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/rooster-cco-gavin-mcinnes-asked-take-leave-absence-159536 |accessdate=19 August 2014 |newspaper=Adweek |date=15 August 2014}}</ref> McInnes defended the article by saying "All I was saying was [[transsexual]]s have a huge suicide rate", and calling the reaction "fake hysteria".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailycaller.com/2014/09/02/fired-writer-gavin-mcinnes-politically-correct-outrage-is-like-the-mob/|title=Fired Writer Gavin McInnes: Politically Correct Outrage Is Like The Mob|website=The Daily Caller|access-date=1 April 2016}}</ref>
In June 2015, broadcaster [[Anthony Cumia]] announced that McInnes would be hosting a show on his network, therefore retiring the Free Speech podcast that he had started in March. ''The Gavin McInnes Show'' premiered on [[Compound Media]] on 15 June. McInnes is a former contributor to Canadian far-right portal [[The Rebel Media]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nationalpost.com/news/canada/politicians-contributors-distance-themselves-as-rebel-medias-meltdown-continues|title=Rebel Media meltdown: Faith Goldy fired as politicians, contributors distance themselves|last=|first=|date=18 August 2017|work=National Post|access-date=4 September 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> and a regular on [[conspiracy theory|conspiracy theorist]] media platform [[Infowars]]' ''[[Alex Jones (radio host)|The Alex Jones Show]]'', and Fox News' ''[[Red Eye (TV series)|Red Eye]]'', ''[[The Greg Gutfeld Show]]'', and ''[[The Sean Hannity Show]]''. He writes for ''[[Taki's Magazine]]''<ref>{{cite web|last=Theodoracopulos |first=Taki |url=http://takimag.com/contributor/gavinmcinnes/151#axzz2ZzkCQCec |title=Taki's Magazine - Contributors |website=Takimag.com |date= |accessdate=10 March 2016}}</ref> and previously wrote for [[TruthRevolt]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Gavin McInnes|publisher=[[TruthRevolt]]|url=http://www.truthrevolt.org/author/gavin-mcinnes|accessdate=29 October 2017}}</ref> [[SpinMedia|Death and Taxes]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.deathandtaxesmag.com/6655/guest-article-gavin-mcinnes-discusses-roman-polanski-and-child-predators/|title=Guest Article: Gavin McInnes Discusses Roman Polanski And Child Predators|website=Death and Taxes|access-date=1 April 2016}}</ref> [[The Federalist (website)|The Federalist]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thefederalist.com/2016/03/15/why-your-top-10-reasons-for-not-having-kids-are-stupid/|title=Why Your Top 10 Reasons For Not Having Kids Are Stupid|website=Thefederalist.com|access-date=1 April 2016}}</ref> ''[[American Renaissance (magazine)|American Renaissance]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amren.com/author/gavinmcinnes/|title=Gavin McInnes, Author at American Renaissance|website=American Renaissance}}</ref> and [[VDARE]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vdare.com/users/gavin-mcinnes |title=Gavin McInnes | VDARE - premier news outlet for patriotic immigration reform |website=Vdare.com |accessdate=10 March 2016}}</ref> McInnes tweeted in December 2015 that every case of [[domestic abuse]] he knows about "was the result of some cunt trying to ruin [a man’s] life";<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.salon.com/2017/03/16/bad-boy-gone-worse-is-vice-co-founder-gavin-mcinnes-flirting-with-a-dangerous-fringe/|title=Bad boy gone worse: Vice co-founder Gavin McInnes slides from right-wing provocateur to the neo-Nazi fringe|first=Amanda|last=Marcotte|website=Salon.com|date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> he had previously written that women "want to be downright abused".<ref>{{cite news|last=McInnes|first=Gavin|title=Everything I Learned in College Was a Lie|url=http://takimag.com/article/everything_i_learned_in_college_was_a_lie_gavin_mcinnes/print#axzz4FcymChAN|publisher=[[Taki's Magazine]]}}</ref> In 2016, McInnes referred to [[Jada Pinkett Smith]] as a "monkey actress" on his radio show.<ref name="VV">{{cite news|last1=Campbell|first1=Jon|title=Gavin McInnes Wants You to Know He’s Totally Not a White Supremacist |url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2017/02/15/gavin-mcinnes-wants-you-to-know-hes-totally-not-a-white-supremacist/|work=Village Voice|date=15 February 2017}}</ref>
On 2 February 2017, in an episode of his [[YouTube]] show "The Rebel", McInnes announced his resignation from Fox News.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.therebel.media/10_secrets_about_fox_news_now_that_i_quit|title=10 Secrets About Fox News (Now That I've Quit)|website=Therebel.media|accessdate=29 October 2017}}</ref>
McInnes left Rebel Media in August 2017, declaring that he was going to be "a multi-media [[Howard Stern]]–meets–[[Tucker Carlson]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.therebel.media/the_real_reason_i_left_the_rebel/|title=The REAL reason I left The Rebel|date=25 August 2017|website=therebel.media}}</ref> He later joined CRTV, an online television network launched by [[Conservative Review]]. The debut episode of his new show ''Get Off My Lawn'' aired on 22 September 2017.<ref>{{Citation|title=Get Off My Lawn Debut Episode {{!}} Part 1 - CRTV|url=https://www.crtv.com/video/get-off-my-lawn-debut-episode--part-1|website=Crtv.com|accessdate=2017-09-22}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=Get Off My Lawn Debut Episode {{!}} Part 2 - CRTV|url=https://www.crtv.com/video/get-off-my-lawn-debut-episode--part-2|website=Crtv.com|accessdate=2017-09-22}}</ref> On 10 August 2018, McInnes's [[Twitter]] account, as well as the account for the Proud Boys, was permanently suspended by Twitter due to their rules against violent extremist groups. The suspension was ahead of the one-year anniversary of the Unite the Right rally, and the scheduled [[2018 Unite the Right rally]].<ref name="twitter1">{{cite news |last1=Mac |first1=Ryan |last2=Montgomery |first2=Blake |title=Twitter Suspends Proud Boys And Founder Gavin McInnes Accounts Ahead Of Unite The Right Rally |url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/ryanmac/twitter-suspends-proud-boys-and-founder-gavin-mcinnes |accessdate=11 August 2018 |work=BuzzFeed News |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Roettgers |first1=Janko |title=Twitter Shuts Down Accounts of Vice Co-Founder Gavin McInnes, Proud Boys Ahead of ‘Unite the Right’ Rally |url=https://variety.com/2018/digital/news/twitter-shuts-down-accounts-of-vice-co-founder-gavin-mcinnes-proud-boys-ahead-of-unite-the-right-rally-1202902397/ |accessdate=11 August 2018 |work=Variety |date=10 August 2018}}</ref>
On 12 October 2018, McInnes participated in a reenactment of the 1960 assassination of [[Inejiro Asanuma]] by [[Otoya Yamaguchi]] at the Metropolitan Republican Club. After the event, a contingent of Proud Boys were caught on tape beating a protester outside the venue,<ref>{{cite web |title=Gavin McInnes 'Personally I think the guy was looking to get beat up for optics' |url=https://spectator.us/2018/10/gavin-mcinnes/ |website=Spectator USA |accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> after members of [[Antifa (United States)|Antifa]] threw a plastic bottle of urine at them.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Feuer |first1=Alan |title=Founder of Proud Boys Says He’s Arranging Surrender of Men in Brawl |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/19/nyregion/the-proud-boys-gavin-mcinnes-arrested.html |work=The New York Times |date=October 16, 2018 |language=en |quote=The police said the violence started after one of the leftist protesters threw a plastic bottle at the Proud Boys, who had with them members of far-right groups, like the 211 Bootboys and Batalion 49.}}</ref>
On November 21st, shortly after news broke that the FBI had classified the Proud Boys as an extremist group with ties to white nationalists, McInnes said that his lawyers had advised him that quitting might help the nine members being prosecuted for the incidents in October and he said "this is 100% a legal gesture, and it is 100% about alleviating sentencing", and said it was a "stepping down gesture, in quotation marks".<ref>{{cite news |title=Proud Boys founder Gavin McInnes quits 'extremist' far-right group|author=Wilson, Jason|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/nov/22/proud-boys-founder-gavin-mcinnes-quits-far-right-group |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=November 21, 2018|accessdate=November 22, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Prengel |first1=Kate |title=Gavin McInnes Says He Is Quitting the Proud Boys [VIDEO] |url=https://heavy.com/news/2018/11/gavin-mcinnes-quits-proud-boys-video/ |work=Heavy.com |date=November 21, 2018}}</ref>
Later that month, McInnes was planning on traveling to Australia for a speaking tour with [[Milo Yiannopolous]] and [[Tommy Robinson (activist)|Tommy Robinson]] (Stephen Yaxley-Lennon), but was informed by Australian immigration authorities that "he was judged to be of bad character" and would be denied a visa to enter the country. Issuing a visa to McInnes was opposed by an online campaign called "#BanGavin", which collected 81,000 signatures.<ref>Wilson, Jason (November 30, 2018) [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/nov/30/gavin-mcinnes-proud-boys-australia-visa "Gavin McInnes: founder of far-right Proud Boys denied Australian visa – report"] ''[[The Guardian]]''</ref>
== Views == McInnes describes himself as [[libertarian]]<ref>{{Citation|last=MILO|title=MILO Meets Gavin McInnes|date=2017-10-23|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qtu0E9ERXQ4|accessdate=2017-11-28}}</ref> and part of the [[New Right#Third New Right|New Right]], a term that he prefers to use rather than [[alt-light]].<ref>{{Citation|last=McInnes|first=Gavin|title=Alt Light is a gay term that sounds like a diet soda in bed w Alt Right. We're "The New Right."|url=https://twitter.com/gavin_mcinnes/status/832718774809788417}}</ref> ''The New York Times'' has described McInnes as a "far-right provocateur."<ref name=":0"></ref>
McInnes has referred to himself as a "western chauvinist" and started a men's organization called [[Proud Boys]] who swear their allegiance to this cause.<ref> *{{cite web|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/crime/seattle-police-wary-of-may-day-violence-between-pro-and-anti-trump-groups/|author=Carter, Mike|title=Seattle police wary of May Day violence between pro- and anti-Trump groups|publisher=''Seattle Times''|date=1 May 2017}} *{{cite web|url=https://apnews.com/964cc747d67e4ae6863b07acb3c52539/protests-erupt-nyu-amid-event-conservative-speaker|author=Long, Colleen|title=11 arrests at NYU protest over speech by 'Proud Boys' leader|publisher=''Associated Press''|date=3 February 2017}} *{{cite web|last1=Tasker|first1=John Paul|title=Head of Canada's Indigenous veterans group hopes Proud Boys don't lose their CAF jobs|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/indigenous-veterans-group-proud-boys-1.4191749|website=CBC|publisher=CBC}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x2momlh|last1=McInnes|first1=Gavin|last2=Lewis|first2=Jeffrey|publisher=Daily Motion|title=Free Speech|accessdate=14 October 2016}}</ref> The [[FBI]] classifies the Proud Boys "an extremist group with ties to white nationalism", according to a document produced by Washington state law enforcement,<ref name="guardianfbi">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/nov/19/proud-boys-fbi-classification-extremist-group-white-nationalism-report|title=FBI now classifies far-right Proud Boys as 'extremist group', documents say|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=19 November 2018}}</ref> and the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] classifies it as a hate group.<ref name="splc">{{cite news|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/extremist-files/group/proud-boys|title=Proud Boys|website=Southern Poverty Law Center |access-date=19 November 2018}}</ref> McInnes says that his group is not white nationalist.<ref name="guardianfbi"/>
In 2003 McInnes said, "I love being white and I think it's something to be very proud of. I don't want our culture diluted. We need to close the borders now and let everyone assimilate to a Western, white, English-speaking way of life."<ref name="Grigoriadis">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/28/style/the-edge-of-hip-vice-the-brand.html|accessdate=15 October 2018|website=[[The New York Times]]|title=The Edge of Hip: Vice, the Brand|first=Vanessa|last=Grigoriadis|date=28 September 2003}}</ref>
===Race and ethnicity=== McInnes has been accused of racism<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.news.com.au/finance/business/media/proud-boys-founder-gavin-mcinnes-heading-to-australia-in-november/news-story/3ae40fb92050ba6b322c4a7c9351c7a9 |title=Proud Boys founder Gavin McInnes heading to Australia in November |date=21 August 2018 |publisher=[[news.com.au]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.qt.com.au/news/proud-boys-founder-gavin-mcinnes-heading-to-austra/3498904/ |title=Right-wing activist heading to Australia |date=21 August 2018 |publisher=''[[The Queensland Times]]''}}</ref> and of promoting white supremacist rhetoric.<ref name=":0" /> He has stated alleged racial slurs against [[Susan Rice]] and [[Jada Pinkett Smith]] personally,<ref name="VillageVoice">{{cite news|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2017/02/15/gavin-mcinnes-wants-you-to-know-hes-totally-not-a-white-supremacist/ |title=Gavin McInnes Wants You to Know He’s Totally Not a White Supremacist |date=15 February 2017 |author=Jon Campbell |publisher=''[[The Village Voice]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/07/10/the-alt-rights-proud-boys-love-fred-perry-polo-shirts-the-feeling-is-not-mutual/ |title=The alt-right’s Proud Boys love Fred Perry polo shirts. The feeling is not mutual. |date=10 July 2017 |author=Kyle Swenson |publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''}}</ref> and more widely against [[Palestinians]] and [[Asian people|Asians]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/2/7/16976180/chelsea-manning-alt-right |title=We need to talk about Chelsea Manning |date=15 February 2017 |publisher=''[[The Verge]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2017/04/25/new-fight-club-ready-street-violence |title=New "Fight Club" Ready for Street Violence |date=25 April 2017 |publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}}</ref> McInnes has said that there is a "mass conformity that black people push on each other",<ref>{{cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/US/proud-boys-oath-keepers-controversial-groups-involved-major/story?id=56687836 |title=The Proud Boys and the Oath Keepers: 2 controversial groups involved in major protests |date=19 July 2018 |publisher=[[ABC News]]}}</ref> and in 2018, he said there was significant "black violence" in the United States, with 8,000 cases a year of black-on-black murder.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mediamatters.org/video/2018/05/14/gavin-mcinnes-childish-gambinos-america-black-violence-bonfire/220201 |title=Gavin McInnes on Childish Gambino's This Is America: "Black violence is a bonfire" |date=14 May 2018 |publisher=[[Media Matters]]}}</ref>
===Judaism and anti-Semitism=== In March 2017, during a trip to Israel with The Rebel Media, McInnes made controversial comments defending [[Holocaust deniers]], accused the Jews of being responsible for the [[Holodomor]] and the [[Treaty of Versailles]], and said he was "becoming anti-Semitic". He later said his comments were taken out of context.<ref>{{cite web | url =https://www.therebel.media/what_gavin_mcinnes_really_thinks_about_the_holocaust | title =What Gavin McInnes really thinks about the Holocaust | last =McInnes | first =Gavin | date =12 March 2017 | website =The Rebel Media }}</ref> McInnes also produced a comedic video for Rebel called "Ten Things I Hate about Jews", later retitled "Ten Things I Hate About Israel".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalobserver.com/2017/03/15/news/rebel-media-defending-contributor-behind-repulsive-rant-was-praised-white|title=Rebel Media is defending contributor behind 'repulsive rant' that was praised by white supremacists|first=Riley |last=Sparks|date=15 March 2017|website=Nationalobserver.com|accessdate=29 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="auto"/> In response to the controversy, McInnes said: “I landed, and I’ve got tons of Nazi friends. David Duke and all the Nazis totally think I rock... No offence, Nazis, I don’t want to hurt your feelings, but I don’t like you. I like Jews.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cjnews.com/news/canada/rebel-media-star-gets-flak-10-things-hate-jews-video|title=Rebel's Gavin McInnes gets flak from CIJA for offensive videos about Jews and Israel|first=Ron Csillag, Staff|last=Reporter|date=17 March 2017|website=Cjnews.com|accessdate=29 October 2017}}</ref>
===Islam=== McInnes is [[Islamophobia|anti-Islam]].<ref name="VillageVoice" /><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wpr.org/controversial-proud-boys-embrace-western-values-reject-feminism-and-political-correctness |title=Controversial Proud Boys Embrace 'Western Values,' Reject Feminism And Political Correctness |date=26 November 2017 |publisher=[[Wisconsin Public Radio]]}}</ref> He has said that "Muslims are stupid ... the only thing they really respect is [[violence]] and being tough."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://nationalpost.com/features/inside-ezra-levants-rebel-media |title=Inside Rebel Media |date=16 August 2018 |publisher=''[[National Post]]''}}</ref> He also has equated Islam with fascism, stating "[[Nazis]] are not a thing. Islam is a thing."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rightwingwatch.org/post/gavin-mcinnes-nazis-are-not-a-thing-islam-is-a-thing/ |title=Gavin McInnes: ‘Nazis Are Not A Thing. Islam Is A Thing’ |date=18 August 2017 |publisher=[[Right Wing Watch]]}}</ref> In April 2018, Mcinnes labelled a significant section of Muslims as both [[mentally ill]] and [[incestuous]], claiming that "Muslims have a problem with inbreeding. They tend to marry their first cousins... and that is a major problem [in the U.S.] because when you have mentally damaged inbreds – which not all Muslims are, but a disproportionate number are – and you have a hate book called the [[Koran]]... you end up with a perfect recipe for [[mass murder]]."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/extremist-files/group/proud-boys |title=Proud Boys |publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.theskanner.com/news/newsbriefs/27253-37-organizations-and-a-regional-organization-representing-over-50-tribes-denounce-bigotry-and-violence-before-patriot-prayer-and-proud-boys-rally-in-portland-on-august-4 |title=37 Organizations and a Regional Organization Representing Over 50 Tribes Denounce Bigotry and Violence before Patriot Prayer and Proud Boys Rally in Portland on August 4 |date=3 August 2018 |publisher=''[[The Skanner]]''}}</ref>
===Gender=== McInnes has described himself as "an [[Archie Bunker]] sexist."<ref name=":0" />
As early as 2003, [[Vanessa Grigoriadis]] in ''The New York Times'' quoted McInnes saying, "'No means no' is puritanism. I think Steinem-era feminism did women a lot of injustices, but one of the worst ones was convincing all these indie norts that women don't want to be dominated."<ref name="Grigoriadis" /> McInnes has been accused of [[sexism]] by various [[media outlets]] including ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'',<ref>{{cite news |last=Sutton |first=Scott |author-link= |date=15 May 2015 |title=Gavin McInnes might be the most sexist man on the planet |url=http://national.suntimes.com/national-politics/7/72/1126269/gavin-mcinnes-most-sexist-man-on-the-planet/ |dead-url=yes |department=National |work=Chicago Sun-Times |publisher= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518013148/http://national.suntimes.com/national-politics/7/72/1126269/gavin-mcinnes-most-sexist-man-on-the-planet|archive-date=2015-05-18|access-date= }}</ref> ''[[Independent Journal Review]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ijr.com/2015/05/326424-gavin-mcinnes-explains-sexist-comments-that-ruffled-feathers-by-totally-doubling-down-on-them/ |title=Gavin McInnes Explains 'Sexist' Comments That Ruffled Feathers...By Totally Doubling Down on Them |last=Bonk |first=Lawrence |author-link= |date=20 May 2015 |website=[[Independent Journal Review]] |access-date= }}</ref> ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.salon.com/2017/03/16/bad-boy-gone-worse-is-vice-co-founder-gavin-mcinnes-flirting-with-a-dangerous-fringe/ |title=Bad boy gone worse: Is Vice co-founder Gavin McInnes flirting with a dangerous fringe? |last=Marcotte |first=Amanda |author-link= |date=16 March 2017 |website=[[Salon (website)]] |publisher= |access-date= }}</ref> ''[[Jezebel (website)|Jezebel]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jezebel.com/vice-co-founder-throws-epic-tantrum-about-women-defying-1450163938|title=Vice Co-Founder Throws Epic Tantrum About Women Defying Gender Roles|first=Madeleine|last=Davies |date=22 October 2013 |website=[[Jezebel (website)]]}}</ref> ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/gavin-mcinnes-interview-im-not-796177|title=Vice Co-Founder Gavin McInnes on Trolling Feminists: I'm Not Andy Kaufman; This Isn't a Joke|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=29 October 2017}}</ref> and ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2013/10/31/gavin_mcinnes_says_women_work_because_they_are_forced_to_pretend_to_be_men.html |title=Most Women Work Because They Have To|first=Amanda|last=Marcotte|date=31 October 2013|website=Slate.com}}</ref> In October 2013, McInnes said during a panel interview that "people would be happier if women would stop pretending to be men", and that [[feminism]] "has made women less happy".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2013/10/vice-co-founder-gavin-mcinnes-feminism-has-made-women-less-happy/ |title=Gavin McInnes: 'Feminism has Made Women Less Happy' |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=22 October 2013 |accessdate=31 October 2013}}</ref> He explained that "We've trivialized childbirth and being domestic so much that women are forced to pretend to be men. They're feigning this toughness, they're miserable."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/21/gavin-mcinnes-women-workplace_n_4138741.html |title=Gavin McInnes Launches Expletive-Laden Tirade About Women In The Workplace (VIDEO) |work=Huffington Post |date=21 October 2013|accessdate=31 October 2013 |first=Ryan |last=Buxton}}</ref> A heated argument ensued with [[University of Miami School of Law]] professor [[Mary Anne Franks]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Ciara LaVelle|url=http://blogs.miaminewtimes.com/cultist/2013/10/university_of_miami_law_profes.php |title=UM Law Professor Mary Anne Franks Issues Epic Feminist Beatdown on Vice Founder Gavin McInnes |work=[[Miami New Times]] |date=24 October 2013 |accessdate=31 October 2013}}</ref>
===White genocide=== McInnes has espoused the [[white genocide conspiracy theory]] saying that white women having abortions<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/aug/17/charlottesville-alt-right-neo-nazis-white-nationalists |title=Neo-Nazis, white nationalists, and internet trolls: who's who in the far right |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=August 17, 2017}}</ref> and immigration is "leading to white genocide in the West".<ref> *{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2017/08/10/do-you-want-bigots-gavin-because-how-you-get-bigots|title=Do You Want Bigots, Gavin? Because This Is How You Get Bigots|publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}} *{{cite web|url=https://rewire.news/article/2017/08/28/hate-goes-mainstream-gavin-mcinnes-proud-boys/ |title=How Hate Goes ‘Mainstream’: Gavin McInnes and the Proud Boys |publisher=[[Rewire.News]] |date=August 28, 2017}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.citypaper.com/news/dic/bcp-102517-dic-proud-boys-20171025-story.html |title=Proud Boy lawyer demands alt-weeklies not call "western chauvinist fraternity" alt-right |publisher=''[[Baltimore City Paper]]'' |date=October 25, 2017}} *{{cite web|url=https://www.portlandmercury.com/blogtown/2017/12/12/19540403/proud-boys-founder-wants-to-trigger-the-entire-state-of-oregon-by-helping-patriot-prayers-joey-gibson-win-the-oregon-person-of-the-year-p |title="Proud Boys" Founder Wants to "Trigger the Entire State of Oregon" by Helping Patriot Prayer's Joey Gibson win the Oregon Person of the Year Poll|publisher=''[[The Portland Mercury]]'' |date=December 12, 2017}}</ref> In 2018, regarding [[South African farm attacks]] and [[Land reform in South Africa|land reform proposals]], he said that [[Ethnic groups in South Africa#Black Population|black South Africans]] were not "trying to get their land back – they never had that land", instead claiming there were "ethnic cleansing" efforts against [[white South Africans]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mediamatters.org/people/gavin-mcinnes |title=With Trump’s South Africa tweet, Tucker Carlson has turned a white nationalist narrative into White House policy |date=23 August 2018 |publisher=[[Media Matters]]}}</ref>

[[File:Эмблема Правительства ПМР.png|thumb|Government seal of Transnistria.]] {{Politics of Transnistria}}
The '''Government of the Pridnestrovian Moldavian Republic''' is the political leadership of the unrecognized, but [[de facto]] independent, [[Pridnestrovian Moldavian Republic]], better known in English as Transnistria.
==Executive branch==
Transnistria is headed by a [[President of Transnistria|president]], the current president is [[Vadim Krasnoselsky]]. They are served by a cabinet of ministers, which is headed by the [[Prime Minister of Transnistria|Prime Minister]]; the incumbent is [[Aleksandr Martynov (Transnistrian politician)|Aleksandr Martynov]]. Transnistria uses a [[semi-presidential system]], where the president is [[head of state]] and the prime minister is [[head of government]].
Transnistria used to have a [[Vice President of Transnistria|vice president]], but this position was abolished after the [[Transnistrian presidential election, 2011|2011 elections]], after the constitution had been amended earlier in the year. The last vice president was [[Aleksandr Ivanovich Korolyov|Aleksandr Korolyov]].
==Current cabinet==

Source: [http://gov-pmr.org/gov/composition/]
==Legislative branch== [[File:Tiraspolsupremesovietleninstatue07052011.jpg|thumb|200px|Statue of [[Lenin]] in front of Supreme Soviet, Tiraspol.]] The [[Parliament of Transnistria|Supreme Council or Supreme Soviet]] is the parliament of the Pridnestrovian Moldavian Republic.

[[File:Andrew Johnson impeachment trial.jpg|350px|thumb|[[Theodore R. Davis]]'s illustration of President Johnson's impeachment trial in the Senate, published in ''[[Harper's Weekly]].'']] The '''Impeachment of Andrew Johnson''' occurred in 1868, when the [[United States House of Representatives]] resolved to [[Impeachment in the United States|impeach]] [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Andrew Johnson]], adopting eleven [[articles of impeachment]] detailing his "[[high crimes and misdemeanors]]", in accordance with [[Article Two of the United States Constitution]]. The House's primary charge against Johnson was violation of the [[Tenure of Office Act (1867)|Tenure of Office Act]], passed by the [[40th United States Congress|U.S. Congress]] in March 1867, over the President's [[veto]]. Specifically, he had removed from office [[Edwin M. Stanton|Edwin McMasters Stanton]], the [[United States Secretary of War|Secretary of War]]—whom the Act was largely designed to protect—and attempted to replace him with [[Brevet (military)|Brevet]] Major General [[Lorenzo Thomas]]. (Earlier, while the Congress was not in session, Johnson had suspended Stanton and appointed General [[Ulysses S. Grant]] as Secretary of War ''[[ad interim]].'')
The House approved the articles of impeachment on March 2–3, 1868, and forwarded them to the [[United States Senate|Senate]]. The trial in the Senate began three days later, with [[Chief Justice of the United States]] [[Salmon P. Chase]] presiding. On May 16, the Senate failed to convict Johnson on one of the articles, with the 35–19 vote in favor of conviction falling short of the necessary [[two-thirds majority]] by a single vote. A ten-day recess was called before attempting to convict him on additional articles. The delay did not change the outcome, however, as on May 26, it failed to convict the President on two articles, both by the same margin; after which the trial was adjourned.
This was the first impeachment of a President since creation of the office in 1789. The culmination of a lengthy political battle between Johnson, a lifelong [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] and the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] majority in Congress over how best to deal with the defeated Southern states following the conclusion of the [[American Civil War]], the impeachment, and the subsequent trial (and acquittal) of Johnson were among the most dramatic events in the political life of the nation during the [[Reconstruction Era]]. Together, they have gained a historical reputation as an act of political expedience, rather than necessity, which was based on Johnson's defiance of an unconstitutional piece of legislation, and which was conducted with little regard for the will of a general public which, despite the unpopularity of Johnson, opposed the impeachment.
Johnson is one of only three presidents against whom articles of impeachment have been reported to the full House for consideration. In 1974, during the [[Watergate scandal]], the [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|House Judiciary Committee]] approved articles of impeachment against [[Richard Nixon]], who [[Presidency of Richard Nixon#Resignation|resigned from office]], rather than face certain impeachment and the prospect of being convicted at trial and removed from office. In 1998, [[Bill Clinton]] was [[Impeachment of Bill Clinton|impeached]]; he, like Johnson, was acquitted of all charges following a Senate trial.
==Background== ===Presidential Reconstruction=== [[File:Andrew Johnson photo portrait head and shoulders, c1870-1880-Edit1.jpg|thumb|right|upright=.85|President [[Andrew Johnson]]]] Tension between the executive and legislative branches had been high prior to Johnson's ascension to the presidency. Following [[Union Army]] victories at [[Battle of Gettysburg|Gettysburg]] and [[Siege of Vicksburg|Vicksburg]] in July 1863, President Lincoln began contemplating the issue of how to bring the South back into the Union. He wished to offer an olive branch to the rebel states by pursuing a lenient plan for their reintegration. The forgiving tone of the president's plan, plus the fact that he implemented it by [[presidential directive]] without consulting Congress, incensed [[Radical Republican]]s, who countered with a more stringent plan. Their proposal for Southern reconstruction, the [[Wade–Davis Bill]], passed both houses of Congress in July 1864, but was [[Pocket veto#United States|pocket vetoed]] by the president and never took effect.<ref name=LincolnDA>{{cite web| url=http://millercenter.org/president/lincoln/domestic-affairs| last=Burlingame| first=Michael| title=Abraham Lincoln: Domestic Affairs| publisher= Miller Center of Public Affairs, University of Virginia| location=Charlottesville, Virginia| accessdate=April 14, 2018}}</ref><ref name=BCnoAJ>{{cite journal| last=Whittington| first=Keith E.| title=Bill Clinton Was No Andrew Johnson: Comparing Two Impeachments| url=https://www.law.upenn.edu/journals/conlaw/articles/volume2/issue2/Whittington2U.Pa.J.Const.L.422(2000).pdf| journal=Journal of Constitutional Law| volume=2| issue=2| publisher=University of Pennsylvania| location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania| pages=422–465| date=March 2000| accessdate=April 14, 2018}}</ref>
The [[assassination of Abraham Lincoln]] on April 14, 1865, just days after the [[Army of Northern Virginia]]'s [[surrender at Appomattox]] briefly lessened the tension over who would set the terms of peace. The radicals, while suspicious of the new president and his policies, believed, based upon his record, that Andrew Johnson would defer, or at least acquiesce to their hardline proposals. Though a Democrat from Tennessee, Johnson had been a fierce critic of the Southern secession. Then after several states left the Union, including his own, he chose to stay in Washington (rather than resign his U.S. Senate seat), and later, when Union troops occupied Tennessee, Johnson was appointed military governor. While in that position he had exercised his powers with vigor, frequently stating that "treason must be made odious and traitors punished".<ref name=BCnoAJ/> Johnson, however, embraced Lincoln's more lenient policies, thus rejecting the Radicals, and setting the stage for a showdown between the president and Congress.<ref>{{cite book| title=Reconstruction: People and Perspectives| editor1-last=Campbell| editor1-first=James M.| editor2-last=Fraser| editor2-first=Rebecca J.| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wGmD0Zl27GIC&pg=PR15#v=onepage&q&f=false| page=xv| publisher=ABC-CLIO| location=Santa Barbara, California| date=2008| isbn=978-1-59884-021-6}}</ref> During the first months of [[Presidency of Andrew Johnson|his presidency]], Johnson issued proclamations of general amnesty for most former Confederates, both government and military officers, and oversaw creation of new governments in the hitherto rebellious states{{snd}}governments dominated by ex-Confederate officials.<ref>{{cite book| last=Trefousse| first=Hans L.| title=Andrew Johnson: A Biography| publisher=W. W. Norton & Company| location=New York City| date=1989| isbn=978-0-393-31742-8| pages=193–213}}</ref> In February 1866, Johnson vetoed legislation extending the [[Freedmen's Bureau]] and expanding its powers; Congress was unable to override the veto. Afterward, Johnson denounced Radical Republicans Representative [[Thaddeus Stevens]] and Senator [[Charles Sumner]], along with [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionist]] [[Wendell Phillips]], as traitors.<ref name=AJkeyevents>{{cite web| title=Andrew Johnson – Key Events| url=https://millercenter.org/president/andrew-johnson/key-events| publisher=Miller Center of Public Affairs, University of Virginia| location=Charlottesville, Virginia| accessdate=May 8, 2018}}</ref> Later, Johnson vetoed a [[Civil Rights Act of 1866|Civil Rights Act]] and a second Freedmen's Bureau bill; the Senate and the House each mustered the two-thirds majorities necessary to override both vetoes,<ref name=AJkeyevents/> setting the stage for a showdown between Congress and the president.
At an impasse with Congress, Johnson offered himself directly to the American public as a "[[tribune]] of the people". In the late-summer of 1866, the president embarked on a national "[[Swing Around the Circle]]" speaking tour, where he asked his audiences for their support in his battle against the Congress and urged voters to elect representatives to Congress in the upcoming [[United States midterm election|midterm election]] who supported his policies. The tour backfired on Johnson, however, when reports of his undisciplined, vitriolic speeches and ill-advised confrontations with hecklers swept the nation. Contrary to his hopes, the [[United States elections, 1866|1866 elections]] led to veto-proof Republican majorities in both houses of Congress.<ref>{{cite book| last=Trefousse| first=Hans L.| title=Andrew Johnson: A Biography| publisher=W. W. Norton & Company| location=New York City| date=1989| isbn=978-0-393-31742-8| pages=234–254}}</ref><ref name=JohnsonDA>{{cite web| url=http://millercenter.org/president/johnson/domestic-affairs| last=Varon| first=Elizabeth R.| title=Andrew Johnson: Domestic Affairs| publisher= Miller Center of Public Affairs, University of Virginia| location=Charlottesville, Virginia| accessdate=April 14, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| title=The American Spirit: U.S. History as Seen by Contemporaries, Volume II: Since 1865| edition=Twelfth| last1=Kennedy| first1=David M.| last2=Bailey| first2=Thomas| pages=17–19| publisher=Cengage Learning| date=2009| isbn=978-0-495-80002-6}}</ref> As a result, Radicals were able to take control of Reconstruction, passing a series of [[Reconstruction Acts]]—each one over the President's veto—addressing requirements for Southern states to be fully restored to the Union. The first of these acts divided those states, excluding Johnson's home state of Tennessee, into five military districts, and each state's government was put under the control of the U.S. military. Additionally, these states were required to enact new constitutions, ratify the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]], and guarantee voting rights for black males.<ref name=BCnoAJ/><ref name=JohnsonDA/><ref>{{cite book| title=Slavery, War, and a New Birth of Freedom: 1840s-1877| last=Hacker| first=Jeffrey H.| edition=revised| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=KzWLBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA144&lpg=PA144&dq=Fourteenth+Amendment.&source=bl&ots=j2eoHW3fcA&sig=1y43R435OdYef73tCDa7JUrTIqk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiqpv_p2_vaAhXHqFkKHVo1ApE4ChDoAQgtMAE#v=onepage&q=Fourteenth%20Amendment.&f=false| publisher=Taylor & Francis| date=2014| isbn=978-0-7656-8324-3| page=144}}</ref>
===Tenure of Office Act=== Congress's control of the military Reconstruction policy was mitigated by Johnson's command of the military as president; however, Johnson had inherited, as Secretary of War, Lincoln's appointee Edwin M. Stanton, a staunch Radical Republican, who as long as he remained in office would comply with Congressional Reconstruction policies.<ref>{{cite book |last=Chernow |first=Ron |authorlink=Ron Chernow |title=Grant |publisher=Penguin Press |location=New York |year=2017 |isbn=978-1-5942-0487-6 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wRYcDgAAQBAJ |page=594}}</ref> To ensure that Stanton would not be replaced, Congress passed the Tenure of Office Act in 1867 over Johnson's veto. The act required the President to seek the Senate's advice and consent before relieving or dismissing any member of his Cabinet (an indirect reference to Stanton) or, indeed, any federal official whose initial appointment had previously required its advice and consent.<ref>{{cite book| last=Trefousse| first=Hans L.| title=Andrew Johnson: A Biography| publisher=W. W. Norton & Company| location=New York City| date=1989| isbn=978-0-393-31742-8| pages=275–299}}</ref><ref name=AJimpeachUSS>{{cite web| title=The Impeachment of Andrew Johnson (1868) President of the United States| url=https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/history/common/briefing/Impeachment_Johnson.htm| publisher=Historical Office, United States Senate| location=Washington, D.C.| accessdate=April 13, 2018}}</ref>
[[File:The situation.jpg|thumb|left|upright=.95|"The Situation", a ''[[Harper's Weekly]]'' editorial cartoon shows Secretary of War Stanton aiming a cannon labeled "Congress" to defeat Johnson. The rammer is "Tenure of Office Bill" and cannonballs on the floor are "Justice".]] Because the Tenure of Office Act did permit the President to suspend such officials when Congress was out of session, when Johnson failed to obtain Stanton's resignation, he instead suspended Stanton on August 5, 1867, which gave him the opportunity to appoint General Ulysses S. Grant, then serving as [[Commanding General of the United States Army|Commanding General of the Army]], [[interim]] Secretary of War.<ref name=USPresidency4vol>{{cite book| last=Burg| first=Robert| title=Chronology of the U.S. Presidency [4 volumes]| editor-last=Manweller| editor-first=Mathew| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yM7E2G0tAiwC&pg=PA545&lpg=PA545&dq=August+5,+1867,&source=bl&ots=zjCePtoqzi&sig=GvSkX1MArLzgXysJVSK2mZHUQiU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiihqbJ0djaAhVEuVMKHeW0CdIQ6AEIeDAJ#v=onepage&q=August%205%2C%201867%2C&f=false| publisher=ABC-CLIO| date=2012| isbn=978-1-59884-645-4| page=545}}</ref> When the Senate adopted a resolution of non-concurrence with Stanton's dismissal in December 1867, Grant told Johnson he was going to resign, fearing punitive legal action. Johnson, assured Grant that he would assume all responsibility in the matter, and asked him to delay his resignation until a suitable replacement could be found.<ref name=AJimpeachUSS/> Contrary to Johnson's belief that Grant had agreed to remain in office,<ref>{{cite book |title=American Ulysses: A Life of Ulysses S. Grant |last=White |first=Ronald C. |authorlink = Ronald C. White|publisher=Random House Publishing Group |year=2016 |isbn=978-1-5883-6992-5 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=TPNRCwAAQBAJ |page=453}}</ref> when the Senate voted and reinstated Stanton in January 1868, Grant immediately resigned, before the president had an opportunity to appoint a replacement.<ref>{{cite book |last=Chernow |first=Ron |authorlink=Ron Chernow |title=Grant |publisher=Penguin Press |location=New York |year=2017 |isbn=978-1-5942-0487-6 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wRYcDgAAQBAJ |page=603}}</ref> Johnson was furious at Grant, accusing him of lying during a stormy cabinet meeting. The March 1868 publication of several angry messages between Johnson and Grant led to a complete break between the two. As a result of these letters, Grant solidified his standing as the frontrunner for the [[1868 Republican National Convention|1868 Republican presidential nomination]].<ref>{{cite book |title=American Ulysses: A Life of Ulysses S. Grant |last=White |first=Ronald C. |authorlink = Ronald C. White|publisher=Random House Publishing Group |year=2016 |isbn=978-1-5883-6992-5 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=TPNRCwAAQBAJ |pages=454–455}}</ref><ref name=USPresidency4vol/>
Johnson agonized about Stanton's restoration to office, and undertook a desperate search for someone to replace Stanton whom the Senate might find acceptable. He turned first to General [[William Tecumseh Sherman]], who was an enemy of Stanton's, but Sherman turned the president down.<ref>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UD14BgAAQBAJ&pg=PR4#v=onepage&q=impeachment&f=false| title=Lincoln's Autocrat: The Life of Edwin Stanton| last=Marvel| first=William| publisher=University of North Carolina Press| date=2015| isbn=978-1-46962249-1| page=437}}</ref> Sherman subsequently suggested to Johnson that Republican radicals and moderates would be amenable to replacing Stanton with [[Jacob Dolson Cox|Jacob Cox]], but he found the president to be no longer interested in appeasement.<ref>{{cite journal| last=Benedict| first=Michael Les| title=A New Look at the Impeachment of Andrew Johnson| url=http://ejournalofpoliticalscience.org/benedict.html| journal=Political Science Quarterly| volume=113| number=3| publisher=Academy of Political Science| date=Fall 1998| accessdate=April 27, 2018}}</ref> On February 21, 1868, the president appointed [[Lorenzo Thomas]], a brevet major general in the Army, as interim Secretary of War, ordered the removal of Stanton from office, and informed the Senate of his actions. Thomas personally delivered the president's dismissal notice to Stanton, who refused either to accept its legitimacy or to vacate the premises. Instead, Stanton informed [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]] [[Schuyler Colfax]] and [[President pro tempore of the United States Senate|President pro tempore of the Senate]] [[Benjamin Wade]] of his plight, then barricaded himself in his office and ordered Thomas arrested for violating the Tenure of Office Act.<ref>{{cite book| last=Trefousse| first=Hans L.| title=Andrew Johnson: A Biography| publisher=W. W. Norton & Company| location=New York City| date=1989| isbn=978-0-393-31742-8| page=306}}</ref> Thomas remained under arrest for several days, until Stanton, realizing that the case against Thomas would provide the courts with an opportunity to [[Judicial review in the United States|review the constitutionality]] of the Tenure of Office Act, had the charges dropped.<ref>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UD14BgAAQBAJ&pg=PR4#v=onepage&q=impeachment&f=false| title=Lincoln's Autocrat: The Life of Edwin Stanton| last=Marvel| first=William| publisher=University of North Carolina Press| date=2015| isbn=978-1-46962249-1| page=443}}</ref>
Johnson's opponents in Congress were outraged by his actions; the president's challenge to congressional authority—with regard to both the Tenure of Office Act and post-war reconstruction—had, in their estimation, been tolerated for long enough.<ref name=BCnoAJ/> In swift response, an impeachment resolution was introduced in the House by representatives Thaddeus Stevens and [[John Bingham]]. Expressing the widespread sentiment among House Republicans, Representative [[William D. Kelley]] (on February 22, 1868) declared:
{{quote|Sir, the bloody and untilled fields of the ten unreconstructed states, the unsheeted ghosts of the two thousand murdered negroes in Texas, cry, if the dead ever evoke vengeance, for the punishment of Andrew Johnson.<ref name=Politico02242015AG>{{cite web| title=House votes to impeach Andrew Johnson, February 24, 1868| last=Glass| first=Andrew| date=February 24, 2015| url=https://www.politico.com/story/2015/02/this-day-in-politics-115420| website=www.politico.com| accessdate=April 24, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| last=Brockett| first=L. P.| page=502| date=1872| publisher=Zeigler, McCurdy| location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania| url=https://archive.org/stream/menofourdayorbio00bro#page/502/mode/2up| title=Men of our day; or, Biographical sketches of patriots, orators, statesmen, generals, reformers, financiers and merchants, now on the stage of action: including those who in military, political, business and social life, are the prominent leaders of the time in this country| via=Internet Archive, 2009}}</ref>}}
==Impeachment== [[File:AJohnsonimpeach.jpg|thumb|right|upright=.85|The impeachment resolution against Andrew Johnson, approved by the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] on February 24, 1868.]] On February 24, 1868 three days after Johnson's dismissal of Stanton, the House of Representatives voted 126 to 47 (with 17 members not voting) in favor of a resolution to impeach the President for [[high crimes and misdemeanors]]. Thaddeus Stevens addressed the House prior to the vote. "This is not to be the temporary triumph of a political party," he said, "but is to endure in its consequence until this whole continent shall be filled with a free and untrammeled people or shall be a nest of shrinking, cowardly slaves."<ref name=Politico02242015AG/>
One week later, the House adopted eleven [[articles of impeachment]] against the President. The articles charged Johnson with: # Dismissing [[Edwin Stanton]] from office after the Senate had voted not to concur with his dismissal and had ordered him reinstated. # Appointing Thomas [[Secretary of War]] ''ad interim'' despite the lack of vacancy in the office, since the dismissal of Stanton had been invalid. # Appointing Thomas without the required [[advice and consent]] of the Senate. # Conspiring, with Thomas and "other persons to the House of Representatives unknown", to unlawfully prevent Stanton from continuing in office. # Conspiring to unlawfully curtail faithful execution of the [[Tenure of Office Act (1867)|Tenure of Office Act]]. # Conspiring to "seize, take, and possess the property of the United States in the [[United States Department of War|Department of War]]". # Conspiring to "seize, take, and possess the property of the United States in the Department of War" with specific intent to violate the Tenure of Office Act. # Issuing to Thomas the authority of the office of Secretary of War with unlawful intent to "control the disbursements of the moneys appropriated for the military service and for the Department of War". # Issuing to Major General [[William H. Emory]] orders with unlawful intent to violate federal law requiring all military orders to be issued through the General of the Army. # Making [[Swing Around the Circle|three speeches]] with intent to "attempt to bring into disgrace, ridicule, hatred, contempt and reproach, the Congress of the United States". # Bringing disgrace and ridicule to the presidency by his aforementioned words and actions.
==Trial== ===Pretrial=== [[File:Bingham-Stevens.jpg|thumb|upright=.80|[[John Bingham|John A. Bingham]] and [[Thaddeus Stevens]] before the Senate presenting the vote on the president's impeachment by the House]]
On March 4, 1868, amid tremendous public attention and press coverage, the 11 Articles of Impeachment were presented to the Senate, which reconvened the following day as a court of impeachment, with Chief Justice Salmon Chase presiding, and proceeded to develop a set of rules for the trial and its officers.<ref name=AJimpeachUSS/> The extent of Chase's authority as presiding officer to render unilateral rulings was a frequent point of contention during the rules debate and trial. He initially maintained that deciding certain procedural questions on his own was his prerogative; but after the Senate challenged several of his rulings, he gave up making rulings.<ref>{{cite web| last=Gerhardt| first=Michael J.| title=Trial of Impeachment| url=https://www.heritage.org/constitution/#!/articles/1/essays/17/trial-of-impeachment| work=Heritage Guide to the Constitution| publisher=Heritage Foundation| accessdate=May 10, 2018}}</ref> On one occasion, when he ruled that Johnson should be permitted to present evidence that Thomas's appointment to replace Stanton was intended to provide a test case to challenge the constitutionality of the Tenure of Office Act, the Senate reversed the ruling.<ref>{{cite book| last=Herrick| first=Neal Q.| title=After Patrick Henry: A Second American Revolution| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R05L973D1KcC&pg=PA207| date=2009| page=207| publisher=Black Rose Books| location=New York City| isbn=978-1-55164-320-5}}</ref>
When it came time for senators to take the [[juror's oath]], [[Thomas Hendricks]] questioned Benjamin Wade's [[impartiality]] and suggested that Wade [[Judicial disqualification|abstain]] from voting due to a conflict of interest. As there was no constitutional provision at the time for filling an intra-term vacancy in the vice presidency (accomplished a century later by the [[Twenty-fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Twenty-fifth Amendment]]), the office had been vacant since Johnson succeeded to the presidency. Therefore, Wade, as President pro tempore of the Senate, would, under the [[Presidential Succession Act]] then in force and effect, become president if Johnson were removed from office. Reviled by the radical majority, Hendricks withdrew his objection a day later and left the matter to Wade's own conscience; he subsequently voted for conviction.<ref>{{cite book| title=The Impeachment of Andrew Johnson| last=Hearn| first=Chester G.| publisher=McFarland| location=Jefferson, North Carolina| date=2000| isbn=0-7864-0863-4}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| last=Foner| first=Eric| author-link=Eric Foner| title=Reconstruction: America's Unfinished Revolution, 1863–1877| year=1988| publisher=HarperCollins| isbn=9780062035868| page=336}}</ref>
The House impeachment committee was made up of: [[John Bingham]], [[George S. Boutwell]], [[Benjamin Butler (politician)|Benjamin Butler]], [[John A. Logan]], [[Thaddeus Stevens]], [[James F. Wilson]], and [[Thomas Williams (Pennsylvania)|Thomas Williams]].<ref>{{cite web| title=List of Individuals Impeached by the House of Representatives| url=http://history.house.gov/Institution/Impeachment/Impeachment-List/| publisher=Office of the Historian and the Clerk of the House's Office of Art and Archives| location=Washington, D.C.| accessdate=May 10, 2018}}</ref> The president's defense team was made up of [[Henry Stanbery]], [[William M. Evarts]], [[Benjamin Robbins Curtis|Benjamin R. Curtis]], [[Thomas Amos Rogers Nelson|Thomas A. R. Nelson]] and [[William S. Groesbeck]]. On the advice of counsel, the president did not appear at the trial.<ref name=AJimpeachUSS/>
The trial was conducted mostly in open session, and the [[United States Senate chamber|Senate chamber]] galleries were filled to capacity throughout. Public interest was so great that the Senate issued admission passes for the first time in its history. For each day of the trial, 1,000 [[color code]]d tickets were printed, granting admittance for a single day.<ref name=AJimpeachUSS/><ref>{{cite web| title=President Andrew Johnson's impeachment trial, 1868| url=https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/art/common/collection_list/1868Impeachment.htm| publisher=Historical Office, United States Senate| location=Washington, D.C.| accessdate=May 14, 2018}}</ref>
===Testimony=== [[File:Impeachment Committee, Hon. George S. Boutwell, Mass., Gen. John A. Logan, Hon. Thomas Williams, Pa., Hon. James F.... - NARA - 528423.jpg|upright=.80|thumb|The House impeachment committee (from a photograph by [[Mathew Brady]]), seated (left to right): [[Benjamin Butler (politician)|Benjamin F. Butler]], [[Thaddeus Stevens]], [[Thomas Williams (Pennsylvania)|Thomas Williams]], [[John A. Bingham]], standing (left to right): [[James F. Wilson]], [[George S. Boutwell]], [[John A. Logan]]]]
On the first day, Johnson's defense committee asked for 40 days to collect evidence and witnesses since the prosecution had had a longer amount of time to do so, but only 10 days were granted. The proceedings began on March 23. Senator [[Garrett Davis]] argued that because not all states were represented in the Senate the trial could not be held and that it should therefore be adjourned. The motion was voted down. After the charges against the president were made, [[Henry Stanbery]] asked for another 30 days to assemble evidence and summon witnesses, saying that in the 10 days previously granted there had only been enough time to prepare the president's reply. [[John A. Logan]] argued that the trial should begin immediately and that Stanberry was only trying to stall for time. The request was turned down in a vote 41 to 12. However, the Senate voted the next day to give the defense six more days to prepare evidence, which was accepted.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Committee on the Judiciary |author2=House of Representatives |author3=Ninety-third Congress |author4=Second Session |title=Impeachment: Selected Materials on Procedure|year=1974|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office|pages=104–5}}</ref>
The trial commenced again on March 30. Benjamin F. Butler opened for the prosecution with a three-hour speech reviewing historical impeachment trials, dating from [[John, King of England|King John of England]]. For days Butler spoke out against Johnson's violations of the Tenure of Office Act and further charged that the president had issued orders directly to Army officers without sending them through General Grant. The defense argued that Johnson had not violated the Tenure of Office Act because President Lincoln did not reappoint Stanton as Secretary of War at the beginning of his second term in 1865 and that he was therefore a leftover appointment from the 1860 cabinet, which removed his protection by the Tenure of Office Act. The prosecution called several witnesses in the course of the proceedings until April 9, when they rested their case.<ref>{{cite book|author=David O. Stewart|title=Impeached: The Trial of President Andrew Johnson and the Fight for Lincoln's Legacy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Sav95Z-KDZcC|year=2009|publisher=Simon and Schuster|pages=207–12}}</ref>
Benjamin R. Curtis called attention to the fact that after the House passed the Tenure of Office Act, the Senate had amended it, meaning that it had to return it to a Senate–House conference committee to resolve the differences. He followed up by quoting the minutes of those meetings, which revealed that while the House members made no notes about the fact, their sole purpose was to keep Stanton in office, and the Senate had disagreed. The defense then called their first witness, Adjutant General Lorenzo Thomas. He did not provide adequate information in the defense's cause and Butler made attempts to use his information to the prosecution's advantage. The next witness was General William T. Sherman, who testified that President Johnson had offered to appoint Sherman to succeed Stanton as Secretary of War in order to ensure that the department was effectively administered. This testimony damaged the prosecution, which expected Sherman to testify that Johnson offered to appoint Sherman for the purpose of obstructing the operation, or overthrow, of the government. Sherman essentially affirmed that Johnson only wanted him to manage the department and not to execute directions to the military that would be contrary to the will of Congress.<ref>{{cite book|author=Stewart|title=Impeached: The Trial of President Andrew Johnson and the Fight for Lincoln's Legacy|page=231}}</ref>
===Verdict=== The Senate was composed of 54 members representing 27 states (10 former Confederate states had not yet been readmitted to representation in the Senate) at the time of the trial. At its conclusion, senators voted on three of the articles of impeachment. On each occasion the vote was 35–19, with 35 senators voting ''guilty'' and 19 ''not guilty''. As the constitutional threshold for a conviction in an impeachment trial is a [[two-thirds majority]] guilty vote—in this case 36 votes—Johnson was not removed from office.
Seven Republican senators were concerned that the proceedings had been manipulated to give a one-sided presentation of the evidence. Senators [[William Pitt Fessenden]] (Maine), [[Joseph S. Fowler]] (Tennessee), [[James W. Grimes]] (Iowa), [[John B. Henderson]] (Missouri), [[Lyman Trumbull]] (Illinois), [[Peter G. Van Winkle]] (West Virginia),<ref>[http://law.jrank.org/pages/13490/Andrew-Johnson-Trial.html "Andrew Johnson Trial: The Consciences of Seven Republicans Save Johnson."]</ref> and [[Edmund G. Ross]] (Kansas), who provided the decisive vote,<ref>[http://www.eyewitnesstohistory.com/john.htm "The Trial of Andrew Johnson, 1868."]</ref> defied their party by voting against conviction. In addition to the aforementioned seven, three more Republicans [[James Dixon]] (Connecticut), [[James Rood Doolittle|James Doolittle]] (Wisconsin), [[Daniel Sheldon Norton|Daniel Norton]] (Minnesota), and all nine Democratic Senators voted not guilty. [[File:Andrew_Johnson_Impeachment_vote_1867.jpg|thumb|left|Judgement of the Senate]] The first vote was taken on May 16 for the eleventh article. Prior to the vote, Samuel Pomeroy, the senior senator from Kansas, told the junior Kansas Senator Ross that if Ross voted for acquittal that Ross would become the subject of an investigation for bribery.<ref>Curt Anders "Powerlust: Radicalism in the Civil War Era" p. 531</ref> Afterward, in hopes of persuading at least one senator who voted not guilty to change his vote, the Senate adjourned for 10 days before continuing voting on the other articles. During the hiatus, under Butler's leadership, the House put through a resolution to investigate alleged "improper or corrupt means used to influence the determination of the Senate". Despite the Radical Republican leadership's heavy-handed efforts to change the outcome, when votes were cast on May 26 for the second and third articles, the results were the same as the first. After the trial, Butler conducted hearings on the widespread reports that Republican senators had been bribed to vote for Johnson's acquittal. In Butler's hearings, and in subsequent inquiries, there was increasing evidence that some acquittal votes were acquired by promises of patronage jobs and cash cards. Nonetheless, the investigations never resulted in charges, much less convictions, against anyone.<ref>Stewart, ''Impeached'' (2009), pp. 240–249, 284–299.</ref>
Moreover, there is evidence that the prosecution attempted to bribe the senators voting for acquittal to switch their votes to conviction. Maine Senator Fessenden was offered the Ministership to Great Britain. Prosecutor Butler said, "Tell [Kansas Senator Ross] that if he wants money there is a bushel of it here to be had."<ref>Gene Davis ''High Crimes and Misdemeanors (New York: William Morrow & Company, 1977), 266–7, 290–1''</ref> Butler's investigation also boomeranged when it was discovered that Kansas Senator Pomeroy, who voted for conviction, had written a letter to Johnson's Postmaster General seeking a $40,000 bribe for Pomeroy's acquittal vote along with three or four others in his caucus.<ref>Curt Anders "Powerlust: Radicalism in the Civil War Era," p. 532-3</ref> Benjamin Butler was himself told by Ben Wade that Wade would appoint Butler as Secretary of State when Wade assumed the Presidency after a Johnson conviction.<ref>Eric McKitrick "Andrew Johnson" (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1988), 507–8</ref> An opinion that Senator Ross was mercilessly persecuted for his courageous vote to sustain the independence of the Presidency as a branch of the Federal Government is the subject of an entire chapter in President John F. Kennedy's book, ''Profiles in Courage.''<ref>John F. Kennedy "Profiles in Courage" (New York: Harper Brothers, 1961), 115–39</ref> That opinion has been rejected by some scholars, such as Ralph Roske, and endorsed by others, such as Avery Craven.<ref name="New York 1969">Avery Craven "Reconstruction" (New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston, 1969), 221</ref><ref>Ralph J. Roske, "The Seven Martyrs?." ''American Historical Review'' 64.2 (1959): 323–330. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1845447 in JSTOR]</ref>
Not one of the Republican senators who voted for acquittal ever again served in an elective office.<ref>Hodding Carter, ''The Angry Scar'' (New York: Doubleday, 1959), 143</ref> Although they were under intense pressure to change their votes to conviction during the trial, afterward public opinion rapidly shifted around to their viewpoint. Some senators who voted for conviction, such as John Sherman and even Charles Sumner, later changed their minds.<ref>Kenneth Stampp, ''Reconstruction'' (New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 1965), 153</ref><ref>Chester Hearn, ''The Impeachment of Andrew Johnson'' (Jefferson, N. C.: McFarland, 2000), 202</ref><ref name="New York 1969"/>

==Later review of Johnson's impeachment== [[File:Senate-Johnson-Impeachment-Trials.jpg|thumb|left|upright=.95|Impeachment of Andrew Johnson.]] In 1887, the Tenure of Office Act was repealed by Congress, and subsequent rulings by the [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] seemed to support Johnson's position that he was entitled to fire Stanton without Congressional approval. The Supreme Court's ruling on a similar piece of later legislation in the 1926 ''[[Myers v. United States]]'' affirmed the ability of the president to remove a [[postmaster]] without Congressional approval, and stated in its majority opinion "that the Tenure of Office Act of 1867 ... was invalid".<ref>[http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/scripts/getcase.pl?court=US&vol=272&invol=52 MYERS v. UNITED STATES], Findlaw {{!}} Cases and Codes</ref>
Lyman Trumbull of Illinois, one of the ten Republican Senators whose refusal to vote for conviction prevented Johnson's removal from office, noted, in the speech he gave explaining his vote for acquittal, that had Johnson been convicted, the main source of the President's political power—the freedom not to agree with the Congress without consequences—would have been destroyed, and the Constitution's system of checks and balances along with it:
<blockquote>Once set the example of impeaching a President for what, when the excitement of the hour shall have subsided, will be regarded as insufficient causes, as several of those now alleged against the President were decided to be by the House of Representatives only a few months since, and no future President will be safe who happens to differ with a majority of the House and two thirds of the Senate on any measure deemed by them important, particularly if of a political character. Blinded by partisan zeal, with such an example before them, they will not scruple to remove out of the way any obstacle to the accomplishment of their purposes, and what then becomes of the checks and balances of the Constitution, so carefully devised and so vital to its perpetuity? They are all gone.</blockquote>
